{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3382569,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-09T13:28:23.946Z","cooked":"

I’m currently working on a “best practices” article around usage of the WPILib Command-based framework for frc-docs. It’s been 5 years since the “v2” framework debuted, and both the library and its usage have evolved quite a bit in that time. The documentation has changed, as well, but is starting to show some structural cracks as teams start doing things that require more flexibility than our basic examples demonstrate.

I don’t have time to write a full set of new documentation, but I do have time to write one or two articles on how teams should structure Command-based robot projects. I’m starting with a general “guiding principles” article, because I think that’s the greatest need right now.

Here’s what I have so far:

Command-based Best Practices

The WPILib Command-based library is very flexible and supports a number of different approaches to robot code structure. No matter how you choose to use the library, however, there are some best-practices you should follow to ensure your code makes the most of the library’s functionality.

This page contains a number of general rules for making the best use of the Command-based library, organized loosely by the class/library feature they apply to. Please remember that these are general principles and not absolute laws. In the wise words of George Orwell: “Break any of these rules sooner than [code] anything outright barbarous.”

Commands

  • Should not be manually scheduled
    • Instead, bind commands to Triggers, or compose them in command groups.
  • Should not be stored as instances/members
    • It is generally unsafe to reuse single command instances in multiple places, so there’s typically no reason to keep a reference to a command instance in the user code. Commands should be composed or bound immediately after creation, from which point their lifecycle is managed by the library.
  • Should be returned from factory functions
    • Since we cannot reuse individual command instances, “factory functions” are the natural way to represent a command that we will want to bind or compose multiple times; each time the factory is called we get a new command instance.
      • Do not put “factory” in the name of your factory functions. Users can tell it is a factory from context and the type signature.
    • The new keyword is a big contributor to code clutter, and should only appear in code at the level where we actually care about the heap allocation occurring. We typically don’t care that creating and binding a command involves allocations, because this is done at startup and has no real performance implications for the code. Factory functions move the new clutter to the Subsystem layer, making the declarative binding much more readable.
  • Should not be composed too deeply across subsystems
    • Command groups are a tight coupling of commands. Command groups obey a requirement algebra - the requirements of a command group are the union of the requirements of its component commands. This is a very rigid rule that only makes sense for actions that are very closely interconnected, because every Subsystem involved in a command group is unable to perform other actions (including default commands) for the entirety of the duration of the command group.
      • The asProxy decorator can help loosen an overly-rigid Command group - but this can quickly get verbose and has some potentially surprising behaviors if not used carefully.
    • For loose coupling of Commands, use Trigger instead.
      • One command can indirectly lead to another by causing a change in robot state tracked by a Trigger to which the second command is bound, rather than being composed in a command group with the second command. In this case, even if the two commands occur on different subsystems, each subsystem will only be reserved while it is actually performing an action.

Subsystems

  • Should only expose interactions with protected hardware/state through Command factories
    • The point of the Subsystem class is to define a “block” or “mutex” for sensitive state (often - but not always - representing hardware resources like motors) that needs to be guarded against simultaneous access by concurrent code (Commands). If it is possible for code outside the subsystem to access this state outside of a command, then the command scheduler is unable to guarantee that it is not being simultaneously accessed.
      • In other words: the scheduler can prevent commands from fighting with each other over protected state, but it cannot prevent commands from fighting with non-command code. Accordingly, non-command code should only be able to touch protected state from inside the subsystem, where the state lives. Any access to the state from outside of the subsystem is a potential for a resource contention error.
    • The best way to avoid unexpected interactions is to make it impossible for them to happen.
  • Should expose boolean state to other subsystems as public final Trigger instance members
    • This makes it very easy to configure loose coupling rather than tight coupling between subsystems. This often works more nicely with the requirement algebra than the tight coupling of command groups.
  • Should not receive injected references to other subsystems
    • Instead, cross-subsystem coordination should occur in the scope where all of the involved subsystems live.

Triggers

  • Should be used to represent general robot states that can/should trigger commands
    • While the most common use of the Trigger class is to represent button inputs, the class itself is meant to represent arbitrary triggering conditions for commands. In addition to driver inputs, these can include any boolean condition you can think of: sensor readings, game states etc.
  • Should be used to coordinate cross-subsystem interactions when command compositions would be too rigid
    • As mentioned above, the command group requirement algebra means that command groups block all involved subsystems for the entire duration of the command group. This can be confusing and interact poorly with default commands if a command group grows too large.
    • Instead, Trigger allows us to trigger one command upon a state change caused by another, giving a “command group-like” flow without actually defining a command group. This “loose coupling” is extremely expressive.
  • Should live as a public final field in the narrowest scope that has access to the relevant state
    • There is no reason to hide a Trigger behind an accessor, since it is just a wrapper around a (void) -> boolean function. Declaring Trigger instances as public final members leads to very ergonomic and easy-to-read code.

I’d love feedback on what I have so far, and suggestions for what to include. Please comment if you have any!

looks good. one thing you might want to mention is that you don’t need to retain a reference to a trigger at all, if you immediately bind it, since the event loop keeps a reference.

another thing you might want to touch on in a doc about “command best practices” is the topic, which has been covered on CD before, of using command.execute as the main driver of behavior, or subsystem.periodic (so that a command just sets a goal in initialize).

truher:

using command.execute as the main driver of behavior, or subsystem.periodic (so that a command just sets a goal in initialize)

Clarification as a best practice is needed for me. I thought command.execute() was generally discouraged and should normally be “hidden” behind “shortcuts.” I thought subsystem.periodic() usage was a no-no as there was a proposal (that was shot down) to eliminate it (my team doesn’t use it).

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":256,"updated_at":"2024-05-09T14:16:00.247Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":1015,"readers_count":1014,"score":252.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":465602,"topic_slug":"command-based-best-practices-for-2025-community-feedback","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/command-based-best-practices-for-2025-community-feedback/465602/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3382625,"name":"Rishi Rao","username":"22raor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/22raor/{size}/127971_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-09T14:37:33.967Z","cooked":"

I agree that this “state” pattern of setting a goal once and having the subsystem continue to reach it is highly useful.

I think a good practice to do this is to have subsystems have Enum classes for discrete states (like Intaking/Stopped), or regular primitives for things like the angle of an arm.

Then, bind InstantCommands that change a target state in the Subsystem.

As for seeking the goal state, that code could be done in periodic within the Subsystem (but some have mentioned that this might be frowned upon?) Regardless, you can also make a default command on each of these subsystems that accomplishes the same purpose (note that you should be careful that your InstantCommands don’t require subsystems if you take this approach).

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":256,"updated_at":"2024-05-09T14:38:54.076Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":929,"readers_count":928,"score":255.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":465602,"topic_slug":"command-based-best-practices-for-2025-community-feedback","display_username":"Rishi Rao","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":53190,"username":"truher","name":"joel truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41300,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8429 Mentor | 4926 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/command-based-best-practices-for-2025-community-feedback/465602/4","custom_user_title":"8429 Mentor | 4926 Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3382666,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-09T15:37:46.429Z","cooked":"

These are the strong bones of structure and someone (I the mentor?) will have to provide flesh so the students understand and some makeup on the flesh so the students use it efficiently. Definitions of concepts such as “factory,” “proxy,” “coupling,” “block,” “mutex” need clarification for junior programmers.
[I’d be happy to help you write example Java code although I admit I don’t understand 100% of this I’m trying to figure it out.]

Some things I look for that I’ve gleaned from WPILib docs, your CD posts and my experience in reviewing code:

Minimize the use of “history/memory” in commands and subsystems. It’s very seductive but if clever thinking can eliminate history or memory between states it’s much easy to understand and avoid the traps and trouble of the programmer not knowing or remembering that unseen memory register.

I’m still not convinced truher’s and 22raor’s “that this “state” pattern of setting a goal once and having the subsystem continue to reach it is highly useful.” is properly mistake-proofing the use of Command-Based. It’s contrary to a previously stated objective of (attempting to) eliminate subsystem periodic(). I claim it’s seductive but not easily used perfectly. Maybe if there were some sort of officially sanctioned tools to make it easy to use consistently and trouble-shoot, I’d feel better about it.

Don’t use the subsystem periodic method. Decisions about state changes are made by triggers of the appropriate command for the new state. (Even if we use memory or persistence in a subsystem, decisions still should be made in commands.)

Use one and only one “default” command. I like a subsystem default to clean up code and help assure a safe state. Multiple defaults are a trap like hidden memory that is forgotten or not remembered right. (The default command not being supported in composite commands is very distressing and I almost don’t recommend using defaults because of that. I may decide to ban defaults from my team’s code.)

A command is only one state of a subsystem. It’s somewhat confusing when you write “TRIGGERS Should be used to represent general robot states that can/should trigger commands.” I understand but it isn’t fully in students’ experience to express it this way, for example, "My house is too hot (state of the house) so the thermostat clicked (house event; not a house trigger) representing the house state is too hot and that click is also an event that triggers the air conditioner state to change from air conditioner state off to air conditioner state on.

There are several potential best practices for “sugary” levels of style.

Utilize the subsystem methods to perform basic actions through method references to them.

Use a method reference instead of the equivalent lambda expression, if possible, e.g. use this::myMethod [don’t use ()->myMethod()].

I prefer to use parallel() instead of .alongWith() so it is more apparent that all the commands in a parallel are equals

I can go either way on the use of .andThen() or sequence(). With sequence() it is more apparent the actual structure of where any decorators are being applied except it’s a little harder to tell where each command begins and ends (watch the commas). The more mysterious .andThen creation of a new composite command is tricky with ensuing decorators but delimiting each command is easier - .andThen() much more obvious than a tiny comma in a particular place.

Composition Commands glitches:
Composite commands lock all their subsystems for the entire duration.
Default commands are not triggered within the composition.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":256,"updated_at":"2024-05-09T15:37:46.429Z","reply_count":6,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":24,"reads":857,"readers_count":856,"score":366.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":465602,"topic_slug":"command-based-best-practices-for-2025-community-feedback","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/command-based-best-practices-for-2025-community-feedback/465602/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3382668,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-09T15:39:39.018Z","cooked":"
22raor:

I think a good practice to do this is to have subsystems have Enum classes for discrete states (like Intaking/Stopped), or regular primitives for things like the angle of an arm.

I think enum states take care to do right - they’re a useful pattern, but you can end up repeating yourself a lot or accidentally “opting out” of the meaningful protections of the library if you’re not careful. Not every subsystem needs an explicit, exhaustive, and mutually-exclusive set of operating states, and defining this explicitly up front can lead to rigid “waterfall design” problems.

The main reason to lean heavily on subsystem periodic is for the sake of consistency/determinacy of execution order. It’s harder to reason about the behavior of the system when calls to protected hardware are being sequenced by the scheduler instead of by the user. However, it also means you have to take more care that the public contract of your subsystem is actually safe for concurrent access. You do not want to do this:

22raor:

note that you should be careful that your InstantCommands don’t require subsystems if you take this approach

If you’re only using InstantCommands that do not require the subsystem, you’re not guarding against simultaneous access and not really using the power of the library. Even if you’re just modifying goal states, that goal state itself is probably protected state if it is automatically being tracked by periodic code, and you should have a mutex guarding access to it.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

Composition Commands glitches:
Composite commands lock all their subsystems for the entire duration.
Default commands are not triggered within the composition.

These are working as intended; there’s no way to change the behavior here without greatly increasing the internal complexity of the scheduler. Trigger and ProxyCommand provide (we feel) acceptable expressiveness even with the rigid composition model, but we definitely need to document it better.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":256,"updated_at":"2024-05-09T15:44:21.848Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":736,"readers_count":735,"score":217.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":465602,"topic_slug":"command-based-best-practices-for-2025-community-feedback","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/command-based-best-practices-for-2025-community-feedback/465602/6","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3382676,"name":"Gavin Matthews","username":"bovlb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-09T15:52:43.035Z","cooked":"
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

It’s contrary to a previously stated objective of (attempting to) eliminate subsystem periodic().

I could be wrong, but I think the move to eliminate Subsystem.periodic is a question of granularity and timing rather than an opposition to subsystems performing tasks periodically.

Some subsystems have to perform multiple separable tasks. If you have a single periodic method, it’s natural to stuff them all in there. If you’re registering periodic methods explicitly (say with TimedRobot.addPeriodic), it’s easier to schedule them separately. For one thing, this means that their timing is reported separately in loop overruns.

Some periodic tasks don’t need to run at the same frequency. Maybe the dashboard only needs to be updated ten times a second. Maybe odometry should be processed more often. If you’re scheduling periodic tasks explicitly, then it’s easier to think about tuning that period.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":256,"updated_at":"2024-05-09T16:04:10.590Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":636,"readers_count":635,"score":227.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":465602,"topic_slug":"command-based-best-practices-for-2025-community-feedback","display_username":"Gavin Matthews","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/TimedRobot.html#addPeriodic(java.lang.Runnable,double)","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"TimedRobot (WPILib API 2024.3.2)","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38743,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)"},"post_url":"/t/command-based-best-practices-for-2025-community-feedback/465602/7","custom_user_title":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3382679,"name":"Rishi Rao","username":"22raor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/22raor/{size}/127971_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-09T16:03:20.041Z","cooked":"

Yeah, I wouldn’t use it for all mechanisms, but I think it’s nice for those with states that result naturally from the mechanism itself (intake down, intake up, or any signaling states like LEDs).

When I said you have to drop the requirements for InstantCommand, I meant only when using a default command to reach state, rather than using periodic. My logic here is that, if your InstantCommand requests the subsystem to change state, then, for one iteration of the event loop, whatever logic is seeking the state (like a default command that commands a motor for example) will stop for that loop iteration.

This is one of the reasons I prefer using periodic and then using InstantCommands w/ requirements. Is there any way to mitigate this issue if you were to use a default command, other than dropping requirements?

It’s easy to accidentally expose bits of the subsystem state that need to be mutexed without a mutex if you have a rich periodic method, mostly. If you follow the “no protected state is accessible except via command” principle it’s still perfectly safe; it’s just a bit harder to follow that principle if you have lots of protected state.

If all motor outputs occur in a command body then this solves itself; if you’re doing periodic motor outputs then you need to do additional work to ensure it behaves correctly.

The worst abuse my team’s subsystem.periodic() and predecessors were subjected to was piling in the state machines into it (ifs, switches, spaghetti code etc.). We are now satisfied with doing state machines through Commands and Triggers.

The periodic nature cannot be eliminated but the sequence of execution can be better controlled within Robot.periodic(). My team does readAllInputs(); schedule.run(); writeAllOutputs(); so we have a consistent set of inputs to use.

The granularity is still at the subsystem level as the Robot.readAllInputs() runs through a list of all the registered subsystem.readAllInputs(). Essentially identical code and structure to using subsystem.periodic() but the sequence or pacing is a bit different as you suggest.

We tend to put if statements in the writeAllOutputs() to reduce Dashboard output but addPeriodic() could be a better practice that we need to look at.

My team software is still evolving and Commands and PathPlanner were well used for the first time this season which is almost a miracle since we didn’t even have time to finish basic Java lessons before January. Commands helped a lot in winning our first Blue Banner (along with a good robot, good drive team and good scouting so we picked our winning alliance).

22raor:

Well, I suppose then periodic is the only solution, but many people seem to oppose the use of periodic at all. What concerns arise when using periodic?

We’ve had a rough season fighting that before; The problem is periodic motor outputs don’t play nicely with Commands trying to claim ownership. So you have to work around it to inject compliance, check for running commands explicitly, or managing states that do/don’t do the conflicting parts. Inevitably something gets screwed up. It’s a lot of work for something very easily avoided.

If you have an internal state machine, they’re easy to migrate to a command. Just move your code from Periodic into a new RunCommand or FunctionalCommand, and set that command as default, or Trigger’d appropriately. By doing so, you get free compliance with Command based operation, as the state machine starts and stops when appropriate.
Commands declared inside a subsystem still have full access to the subsystem internal and private variables, making it a very easy pattern to switch to. You can further clean things up using Trigger(state==X) and CommandSelector , excellent ways to model a state machine execution in a Command context. In these, each state is a command, so you now get initialize() and end() giving free state transition options too.

22raor:

When I said you have to drop the requirements for InstantCommand, I meant only when using a default command to reach state, rather than using periodic

This problem only comes up if you’re using a global setpoint shared with multiple control loops; In which case, having 2 controlling commands is a problem. So you’d certainly want to use a requires so your controlling command can check inputs and re-start any commands.
The better pattern is having goal states be private and owned/managed by the controlling command, which avoids this hazard. In the case of communicating a change to a defaultCommand, this is fine if 1) the command is written to expect volatile setpoint changes, and 2) your default command has a dedicated setpoint to be changed. In those cases, a requires is optional, as there’s no possible unexpected side effects.

Great summary, but we need examples! I am a big proponent of learning by coding and students would benefit even more by having some kind of reference code.

I propose an LED subsystem as an example of “evergreen” subsystem to exemplify some of these best practices. Arguments for LED subsystem:

  • ubiquitous and very easy to tinker with, you only need the board and LED strip (perfect for quick demo, learning tool)
  • protected state (strip memory buffer)
  • sufficient complexity (see functional requirements below)
  • internal implementation logic for LED patterns does not impact overall design

Minimum functional requirements:

  • default state
  • allows state composition, meaning different parts of the strip may convey different information at the same time
    • for example, vision subsystem uses part of LED to convey vision target information, while intake can signal successful acquisition of a game piece
    • important as this adds necessary complexity by allowing multiple subsystems to “interface” with LED subsystem, probably good example for use of triggers
  • non-trivial internal state that may require use of periodic, e.g. to implement time-dependent patterns (pulsating, random, etc.)
  • functional in disabled robot state

Thoughts?

In the sense of flexibility, elaborating on examples or just potential use cases of .withInterruptBehavior(Command.InterruptBehavior.kCancelIncoming); might help. I can see this being a very useful way to block accidental inputs on critical sequences (such as mechanisms doing a handoff, or a mechanism dance to avoid collisions), which might otherwise push teams to utilize a more complex state machine.

Should be returned from factory functions
Do not put “factory” in the name of your factory functions

I want to agree wholeheartedly, save for an anecdote this year: We tried cleaning up our functional interfaces to be consistent and readable, but adding Command wrappers gave us signatures like void Intake::intake() and Command Intake::intake() ; Necessitating some sort of special naming convention. Lacking an obviously better path, we went Intake.getIntakeCommand(), which is… not really cleaner than just naming it Factory. And now our auto-completes for get are extra cluttered.
So while this highlights a convention problem, it doesn’t actually provide a applicable solution to said problem.

Our team’s proposal for next year is to create a Commands subclass in the subsystem to namespace things, ending up with void Intake::intake() and Intake::Commands.intake(). This necessarily forces our commands to be in a single place in the file, autocomplete cleaner, and avoid having to be creative with function names.

Another missing bit of convention: Where do you put all these factories that use multiple subsystems? There’s currently no specific guidance here, so students default to shoving everything in RobotContainer since it has the needed scopes. But, it’s already complicated and bloated enough.

Since we don’t want to abuse static/singleton instances, we end up doing something like this

//specifically pass in all subsystems so they can be named/referenced
CommandFactory = new CommandFactory (chassis,intake,etc) 

Robotcontainer(){
   controller.a().whileTrue(factory.aimAndShoot());
}

but if there’s a better practice, it’d be good to have documented.

tekdemo:

Since we don’t want to abuse static/singleton instances, we end up doing something like this

CommandFactory = new CommandFactory (chassis,intake,etc) 
Robotcontainer(){
   controller.a().whileTrue(factory.aimAndShoot());

We also ended up doing this exact pattern, with an additional requirement that all commands must be defined in this class and subsystems should only expose public interface and never commands. This helped a lot in reducing accidental errors similar to your void Intake::intake(); Command Intake::intake(); example.

tekdemo:
controller.a().whileTrue(factory.aimAndShoot());

I think what you’re saying here is that you have two subsystems: one is responsible for aiming (e.g. drive, turret), and one is responsible for shooting. When the button is pressed and the robot has a game piece, the aiming subsystem should aim and the shooter should spin up. In addition, when the shooter is at target velocity and the aimer is on-target, we should advance the game piece into the shooter (third subsystem?).

Oblarg tells us we should be using triggers to schedule commands. I’m still struggling to see all the implications of this, but here we could create a trigger for “button held and has game piece” and a second for “and also on-target and at-speed”. These boolean questions are being answered by various subsystems, but the trigger abstracts the source. We could also create commands for “Aim”, “Spin-up” and “AdvanceGamePiece”. Is that what’s being recommended? Should the triggers be whileTrue so the behaviour stops when the condition becomes false?

Edit: Perhaps something like:

new Trigger(m_feeder::hasGamepiece)
    .debounce(0.25, Debouncer.kFalling)
    .and(controller.a())
    .whileTrue(
        m_drivetrain.aim()
            .alongWith(m_shooter.spinup())
    )
    .and(m_drivetrain::onTarget)
    .and(m_shooter::atTargetSpeed)
    .whileTrue(m_feeder.feed());

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

Use one and only one “default” command. I like a subsystem default to clean up code and help assure a safe state. Multiple defaults are a trap like hidden memory that is forgotten or not remembered right. (The default command not being supported in composite commands is very distressing and I almost don’t recommend using defaults because of that. I may decide to ban defaults from my team’s code.)

I don’t believe subsystems can have multiple defaults, unless you try to use periodic to drive systems alongside commands; Which many of us agree is a bad idea.

For compositions that need multiple subsystems, this is easily handled by a trigger:

new Trigger(indexer.getCurrentCommand()==null)
.whileTrue(new RunCommand(()->{},intake,indexer));

We did exactly this because while our intake has a meaningful default (stop), our indexer has work to do and cannot handle it’s default task without the intake. So we placed this trigger alongside our other defaultCommand declarations.

I do think this particular example is a great one to include for triggers; It’s useful, extends an existing common function, and non-obvious simply because commands manage themselves so well that getCurrentCommand is rarely needed.

It’s somewhat confusing when you write “TRIGGERS Should be used to represent general robot states that can/should trigger commands.”

I also agree with this to a degree. I tend to think of commands as the state of the bot; A trigger is a transitional part (either a button, or a self-pressed button) and the subsequent command state may or may not persist outside of that input (such as .onTrue/onFalse outliving the trigger edge)
From various posts, I think Oblarg tends to think of Triggers as the actual state itself, with Commands being a response to that controlling trigger state (the edge/transition, or living only for that particular state).
While the concepts aren’t far off, it’s just enough of a hurdle that I often have to re-read some of those Trigger concepts to translate them to my own mental model of a bot.
